image.altText: A young protester holds a placard bearing the words "born to protest".

items.synopsis: Hundreds of demonstrators gathered below South Australian parliament's upper house this morning to voice opposition to changes to the state's protest laws.

title.children: SA protest law change slammed by MP as the 'worst move ever' by a Labor premier

image.altText: Tony Sharley drives a small boat down the river with cliffs in the background

items.synopsis: Two months after Murray floodwaters receded along the river's South Australian reaches, nature is thriving in their wake — and that's music to the ears of conservationists in the region.

title.children: River regions given a new lease of life as floodwaters rejuvenate parched landscapes

image.altText: Four men in handcuffs stand with sheriff's officers outside a yellow brick building

items.synopsis: Four men accused of murdering Ridleyton man Victor Codea have been found guilty of the lesser charge of manslaughter in Adelaide's Supreme Court.

title.children: Four men accused of murdering Victor Codea at Adelaide High School found guilty of manslaughter

image.altText: A man climbing up from train tracks as a train approaches

items.synopsis: Footage of pedestrians engaging in risky behaviour around trains has been released by the state government in a bid to reduce the number of collisions.

title.children: 'Harrowing' footage shows near misses between pedestrians and trains across Adelaide

image.altText: A man in suit and tie sits at a desk speaking.

items.synopsis: Treasury boss Steven Kennedy says he was able to refer PwC to police for investigation thanks to a push by senators to expose the depth of the firm's tax leak scandal.

title.children: 'Clearly disturbing': Treasury referred PwC to police after emails exposed by Senate

image.altText: A birds eye view of brown flood water, with a line of shack roofs alongside a line of trees

items.synopsis: Flood-affected property owners are concerned their council rates will rise in line with the booming property market despite some of their properties being deemed uninhabitable.

title.children: Flooded property owners worry about rate rises linked to valuer-general's valuations

image.altText: Composite image of Josh Elmes

items.synopsis: The grieving parents of one of the teenage victims of the car crash tragedy near Hamilton, in western Victoria, have pleaded with other youths to speak up if a driver is going too fast.

title.children: 'If only he'd said, that's a bit too fast': Parents' heartbreaking plea after teens die in high-speed crash

image.altText: A man surrounded by cameras.

items.synopsis: The Federal Court reveals the defamation action of former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann against the News Corp media organisation has ended.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann settles defamation action against News Life Media

image.altText: A close-up shot of a logo of Crown Resorts on the top of a high-rise building in Perth.

items.synopsis: Crown Resorts and government financial intelligence agency AUSTRAC agree to a $450 million penalty over historical non-compliance with Australia's anti-money laundering laws.

title.children: Crown Resorts fined $450 million over money laundering breaches

image.altText: A court sketch of Malka Leifer.

items.synopsis: A new civil trial alleging sexual abuse by former Melbourne school principal Malka Leifer is averted after a last-minute settlement is reached.

title.children: Malka Leifer civil trial avoided after complainant reaches settlement with school

image.altText: Two fire fighters on a street in front of a burnt out building

items.synopsis: Cadaver-detection dogs will be used to search the rubble for any human remains after the demolition concludes.

title.children: Demolition begins on historic Sydney building destroyed by fire

image.altText: A young female soldier smiles while holding a rifle

items.synopsis: In Ukraine, they call her Witch, but the origins of Olha Bihar's call sign remain almost as secretive as the start date of Ukraine's long-awaited counteroffensive.

title.children: Olha fought in Bakhmut and witnessed the full cruelty of Wagner commanders who forced their own troops into minefields at gunpoint

image.altText: A man wears a lanyard with the Australian Government coat of arms on it.

items.synopsis: The federal government has outlined its plan to fix "pay fragmentation" — large differences in salaries among staff employed at the same level.

title.children: Lowest-paid public servants to receive salary boost under plan to reduce pay gaps

image.altText: A dingo surrounded by dried grass

items.synopsis: The study used a new genetic analysis system that shows dingoes don't have as much dog ancestry as previously studied.

title.children: New research suggests dingoes are far more purebred than previous studies show

image.altText: Adam Brown, a man wearing glasses, smirks for a selfie.

items.synopsis: A man who stabbed his wife to death at their home in Melbourne's eastern suburbs after an argument over their child's kindergarten has been handed a 24-year prison sentence.

title.children: Man who fatally stabbed wife after an argument over their child's kindergarten given 24-year sentence

image.altText: Nakkiah Lui and Miranda Tapsell on Get Krackin

items.synopsis: When Miranda Tapsell appeared on a satire of breakfast TV four years ago and bared her fury at the way the media had been stoking the fires of racism and xenophobia, she also braced herself for a backlash.

title.children: Miranda Tapsell reflects on the 'surprising' reaction to her Get Krack!n racism monologue

image.altText: An aerial view of an orange smokey fire on land, sea in the distance.

items.synopsis: Rangers are continuing to battle what they believe is a suspicious fire in an area that is a crucial habitat for threatened species.

title.children: Island fire on 'sensitive' Great Barrier Reef marine plain deliberately lit, rangers say

image.altText: A large mining dump truck drives across red soil.

items.synopsis: After one of the most prolonged booms in history, running for the best part of a quarter of a century, signs are emerging that Australia's great iron age is beginning to fade, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Australia's iron ore boom is fading. What will replace it?

image.altText: A large pre-fab house

items.synopsis: April's building approvals data shows 11,594 homes were approved for construction last month — down 24.1 per cent on the previous year. Meanwhile Treasury officials are fronting Senate Estimates to answer questions about PwC. Follow live.

title.children: Historic bust facing building sector after 'profitless boom' as approvals hit weakest level in 11 years

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The chief executive of Perth Mint, Jason Waters, will step down after one year in the role. The announcement was made by the state government-owned Gold Corporation (which operates the Australian refiner). It comes after Western Australia said it would launch a review of its ownership of The Perth Mint, as the company battles allegations it sold diluted gold to China from 2018 to 2021. Perth Mint, the world's largest processor of newly mined gold and a member of the London Bullion Market Association, had rejected those allegations. Mr Waters, who joined the company in April 2022, will take up a senior executive opportunity in the private sector after his departure. Gold Corporation chairman Sam Walsh said that Waters had presided over significant and positive change across the organisation. That included the launch of a substantial, fully-funded remediation programme to address historical shortcomings and non-compliance issues, Walsh added in the statement (which did not provide further details). Mr Waters will continue to lead The Perth Mint while he works out his notice period, and the process to recruit a successor will commence immediately, the company said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Perth Mint CEO resigns after one year

children.content: The chief executive of Perth Mint, Jason Waters, will step down
after one year in the role.
The announcement was made by the state government-owned Gold Corporation (which operates the Australian refiner).
It comes after Western Australia said it would launch a review of its ownership of The Perth Mint, as the company battles allegations it sold diluted gold to China from 2018 to 2021.
Perth Mint, the world's largest processor of newly mined gold and a member of the London Bullion Market Association, had rejected those allegations.
Mr Waters, who joined the company in April 2022, will take up a senior executive opportunity in the private sector after his departure.
Gold Corporation chairman Sam Walsh said that Waters had presided over significant and positive change across the organisation.

That included the launch of a substantial, fully-funded remediation programme to address historical shortcomings and non-compliance issues, Walsh added in the statement (which did not provide further details).
Mr Waters will continue to lead The Perth Mint while he works out his notice period, and the process to recruit a successor will commence immediately, the company said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Bad news for both for builders and those seeking a place to live, with the ABS releasing the latest building approvals data for April. The figures show approvals for new houses as well as apartments and townhouses are at their lowest levels in more than a decade. Housing Industry Association senior economist Tom Devitt said that leaves both the residential construction industry and those relying on it to increase housing supply facing a dire outlook. "On a quarterly basis, this leaves detached house approvals 15.4 per cent lower than the same time the previous year, and multi-units down by 38.9 per cent ," he wrote. "This continues the long-lagged response of Australian homebuyers to the RBA's interest rate hiking cycle, with further declines expected in the coming months. "The combination of construction cost blowouts, labour uncertainties, increased compliance costs and taxes on investors has seen approvals for multi-units fall. "These disappointing approvals numbers are occurring as population growth surges with the return of overseas migrants, students and tourists. "This imbalance will see the affordability and rental crisis deteriorate further." The HIA said, over the past three months, seasonally adjusted building approvals had fallen from the levels seen a year earlier in every state and territory, with the biggest drops in the ACT (-49.8%), Victoria (-35.3%), NSW (28.7%) and the NT (-27.3%). CBA economist Belinda Allen said the picture isn't nearly so grim outside the home building sector. "Outside of new residential approvals, the value of non-residential approvals rose by 13.5%/mth in April and is up by 29.8%/yr ," she noted. "The strength partly due to a weak base year, but looking at the three month moving change also shows a lift in entertainment, health care, and other commercial buildings. " Residential alterations & additions were down by 1.2%/mth and 2.7%/yr ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Building slump 'will see the affordability and rental crisis deteriorate further' warns HIA

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Crown Melbourne and Crown Perth (together Crown) has agreed to pay a $450 million fine for its breaches of anti-money laundering laws. Crown and the financial crimes regulator AUSTRAC have filed submissions to the Federal Court, seeking approval for this settlement. The hearing is scheduled for 10 - 11 July before Justice Michael Lee. The court has discretion to decide whether that is an appropriate settlement given the severity of Crown's breaches of the law.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Crown Casino agrees to pay $450 million penalty for breaking the law

children.content: Crown Melbourne and Crown Perth (together Crown) has agreed to pay a $450 million fine for its breaches of anti-money laundering laws.
Crown and the financial crimes regulator AUSTRAC have filed submissions to the Federal Court, seeking approval for this settlement.
The hearing is scheduled for 10 - 11 July before Justice Michael Lee.
The court has discretion to decide whether that is an appropriate settlement given the severity of Crown's breaches of the law.

image.altText: Smoke rises in the sky over the city after a Russian missile strike, amid Russia's attack on Ukraine, in Kyiv.

items.synopsis: Russia fires a barrage of missiles at Kyiv in an unusual daytime attack on the Ukrainian capital following overnight strikes.

title.children: Russia fires missiles on Kyiv in rare daytime attack as residents run for shelter

image.altText: Female expeditioners on a snow covered beach on a remote island.

items.synopsis: It's nine years since cats, rats, and rabbits were officially declared eradicated from sub-Antarctic Macquarie Island, but scientists fear a new threat is challenging its fragile ecosystem.

title.children: 'Rats running up your legs': Macquarie Island free from pests for nine years, so how's it faring?

image.altText: The plane which was carrying the four children was discovered in thick jungle.

items.synopsis: The children went missing after a light plane crash in Colombia on May 1 which claimed the lives of the three adults on board.

title.children: Four children lost in the Amazon, following a plane crash, believed to be alive four weeks later

image.altText: Box of small round orange fruit called Achacha

items.synopsis: In the depths of South America's Amazon Basin, the achachairú, a highly prized tropical fruit, has been cultivated for generations. But in North Queensland is where it is grown on its largest scale.

title.children: When first grown in Australia, this exotic tropical fruit was little-known. Now farmers can't keep up with demand

image.altText: A woman outside a court building in handcuffs.

items.synopsis: Crystal Leanne Hanley — who was arrested over the neglect and manslaughter of her six-year-old daughter — is taken back into custody after breaching her bail conditions twice. WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised this article contains the first name and image of a person who has died.

title.children: Adelaide mother's bail revoked after testing positive for illicit drugs

image.altText: Yatala Labour Prison

items.synopsis: An Adelaide man has been sentenced to up to 14 years in prison after pleading guilty to multiple sexual crimes against his daughter. WARNING: This story contains details readers may find distressing.

title.children: Paedophile father handed 14-year sentence for sex crimes against daughter

image.altText: A woman smiling and holding a baby at a cafe

items.synopsis: Louise Hughes died at a house at a Park Holme in Adelaide's south-west last year.

title.children: Charges against man accused of Louise Hughes' murder dropped

image.altText: A young woman cuddles a French Bulldog with a big smile on her face

items.synopsis: Since the death of their daughter nearly two years ago, Sophie Putland's family has worked tirelessly to advocate for change in the veterinary industry.

title.children: Sophie Putland's family say she loved being a vet, but the abuse she faced really affected her mental health

image.altText: Kendall holds his fist to his mouth as he cries watching something out of frame.

items.synopsis: Succession is over, and we actually have a successor! So, what did we make of that series finale? Join us as we unpack the show, share our series highlights and farewell the Roys one last time. Follow live.

title.children: Join us as we emotionally recover from that Succession finale

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I sure hope so! But there's so much talent, and only so many categories. Sarah Snook and Kieran Culkin are still yet to win Emmys for their performances in Succession, but they have routinely been nominated in the supporting actor categorie s. However it's been heavily rumoured that both will enter in the lead actor categories. That helps clear Snook's pathway a little, as award show favourite Jennifer Coolidge is usually nominated in the supporting actress category for her work on The White Lotus. Things gets a bit crowded in the lead actor category, though. Brian Cox and Jeremy Strong are always nominated for lead actor, but bumping Culkin up might result in HBO deciding to enter Cox in the supporting category instead. There is also huge competition from other shows, with Bob Odenkirk (Better Call Saul) and Pedro Pascal (The Last of Us) no doubt also getting a nom. One thing is for sure though: Succession will definitely be sweeping the awards.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: So is every Succession actor winning an Emmy now?

children.content: I sure hope so! But there's so much talent, and only so many categories.

One thing is for sure though: Succession will definitely be sweeping the awards.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Wow, what a night of television! Probably the most satisfying ending to a show since Breaking Bad and somehow BARRY matched Succession's chaotic energy. 

So what now? What are some shows similar to Succession that capture the same political backstabbing and dark sense of humour? - ConheadForever. I know right! I'm at a loss on what to watch next 😔 I actually wrote about what to watch after finishing Succession back when season three ended. At the top of my list was The Thick of It. It shares A LOT of the same writers of Succession, mainly Jesse Armstrong but also Tony Roche and Georgia Pritchett. The Thick of It is a dark comedy about the workings of Westminster and centres around the fictional Department of Social Affairs and its incompetent staff. There's a couple other shows on my list which you can check out below, but I would be so interested to see what others recommend!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What do we watch now that Succession has ended?

featuredLink.title: Finished Succession? Try these other shows from the same writers

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What have been our favourite lines from the entire series?

- Jenny

image.altText: An archival black and white photo of well-dressed men with shelves of boxes

items.synopsis: This massive plant archive holds more than a million plants collected from Australia over 250 years. Each one tells a story about our past.

title.children: The locations of these plants are a closely-guarded secret. Here's why

image.altText: Engraving on a bracelet owned by Queen Hetepheres in ancient Egypt.

items.synopsis: An analysis of bracelets owned by ancient Egyptian royalty more than 4,500 years ago has found Egypt and Greece were involved in long-distance trade much earlier than realised.

title.children: These bracelets survived tomb robbers and time — now they're helping us understand the 'beginnings of the globalised world'

image.altText: Four army tanks lined up in the grass.

items.synopsis: New budget analysis finds the Australian Defence Force is receiving less "core funding" than before the last election, with parliament this week set to also scrutinise recent controversial overseas military spending decisions.

title.children: Manufacturers 'uneasy' as Australia shifts to offshore military purchases, sees Defence 'core funding' drop $1.5bn

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue shirt looks down at the camera.

items.synopsis: Eileen Cummings recalls physical abuse from missionaries for speaking in her language and a beating with an electric cord, but final compensation and a chance to share her story has finally brought closure to a dark period in Australian history.

title.children: 'Finally, closure': Stolen Generations survivors reach settlement for historic abuse
